absolute largest asset management company in the entire world with many trillions of dollars in assets under management many people feel that they have really the most influence over the market right along with Vanguard so it's always interesting to see what stocks they're buying and in this case these are the five stocks that they spent the most amount of money on this latest quarter. all right speaking of which moving on to purchase number two well we actually have one of my favorites and that is in broadcom ticker symbol avgo which Black Rock added another 14 million more shares of in the quarter bringing the stake up to over $60 billion and worth just a bit over 1% of the portfolio now like I said I've been a fan of broadcom for a few years now specifically for their work in developing custom chips for other companies a type of service that I think couldn't possibly ever go away in the future with the rise of you know Ai and cloud and internet of things and all these new technologies more and more companies are going to really not not only need powerful chips for for those areas but also more importantly customized chips for handling specifically what their business involves so the de the demand for that I think will always be there but another huge reason for why I invested in the stock was because of their massive $69 billion acquisition of VMware which at first the market wasn't too sure about but I argued that it was only going to make them even larger while helping them improve the other services that they provide specifically in areas of AI and cloud and cyber security and and others that really help broadcom diversify as a business too in fact it's been so beneficial to them so far that Bank of America and Goldman Sachs even called them now their top two AI pick alongside Nvidia calling it a critical piece to the ongoing AI infrastructure buildout adding that the acquisition allows them to upsell different products and services to customers on either side just kind of snowballing into more growth for them which is exactly what we're seeing now with financials on fire sales still growing by double digit rates and the stock has also skyrocketed by close to 500% in just the past 5 years alone unfortunately though for anyone not already in the stock it means that you'd have to take on a pretty rich valuation at these currently high levels where it trades about 35% more expensive than the sector on a forward PE basis although I should not the peeg ratio is actually cheaper because of the incredible growth expected from the acquisition in future years still it's probably not the most attractive perhaps stock out there after this climb which also caused the dividend yield to fall down to just a bit over 1% now which is something that used to be a big selling point for the stock was that dividend but I'm personally not buying any more shares at this time myself because I've already built out really the position that I want in this stock however I am still holding them longterm which is more than I can say for Walmart who I have no interest in owning so I'm ranking broadcom higher at number two. do you agree or disagree with my ranking would you make any changes maybe swapping apple with broadcom at number three I could see that I totally understand that but I just think broadcom gets the slight edge here at the moment for the cheaper valuation and growth and and other things anyway.

the final purchase of the list this will be the biggest of all and surprisingly at least to me it was Apple ticker symbol AAPL adding another nearly 43 million more shares of this past quarter bringing the stake up to over a quarter of a trillion dollars and over 5.3% of the overall portfolio now the reason that I say this is surprising to me is for a couple reasons really now don't get me wrong I love how sticky their products and services are feels like they have almost a cult-like following with their customers that seem to buy everything Apple every year and they're making huge progress on Services where most of the growth is coming from for them right now you can see that on this chart here plus they have one of the biggest cash piles in the world to ensure they they'll never go away they can afford to invest in any new technology they ever need to while also buying back a ton of stocks something that always helps their EPS numbers and valuation actually look more attractive than it otherwise would however there's three big negatives for me to note it's the most expensive stock in the entire world at over a $3.7 trillion market cap which I strongly disagree with I think there's several other stocks that should be valued more than them and as for as much cash as they have in my opinion they're still mostly just a one trick pony relying very heavily on iPhone sales with any trickle down revenue from that like in services and airpods and Apple watch stuff like that coming down into the business that don't get me wrong that's not a bad thing it is hugely profitable for them and again they're doing very good with services but it's not all that Diversified in my opinion for example you look at Google right they actually have more smartphone operating system market share with Android than than Apple and yet Android isn't even the first thing you think about when you look at Google's business because they're so well Diversified into so many other things that they do that are also even more profitable for them and yet their market cap is like two trillion billion dollars less than Apple on top of that Apple stock trades over 80% more expensive than the sector on Peg which is fine when you're you know that damn profitable but it's also the second highest on today's list with broadcom being the cheapest and I just feel that as a more long-term growth oriented investor I'm not as attracted to their almost flat performance on the top and bottom line really these past two years that we've seen but sometimes there even be negative growth because of the cyclicality of smartphone sales and how much they rely on that now based on what I just said Apple Bulls might shred me in the comment section but you know just know that I actually like Apple stock in fact I own some of it myself the only reason I'm listing these negatives is to explain to you why I prefer other stocks a bit more at the current moment like Google Amazon Microsoft who are cheaper buys with more interesting Diversified businesses in my opinion and by the way I'm not the only one who thinks that Apple might be a bit overstretched here as both Ray Doo and even Warren Buffett have been huge sellers this past year and Buffett is one of the biggest apple Bulls in the world so in terms of ranking I'm putting Apple at number four I know it's a little shocking there again not because it's a bad stock but only because stocks 1 to three are better options at the current moment at the current valuation in my opinion which can obviously be wrong but hey that's just me I'd love to hear what you all have to say down below do you agree or disagree with my ranking would you make any changes maybe swapping apple with broadcom at number three I could see that I totally understand that but I just think broadcom gets the slight edge here at the moment for the cheaper valuation and growth and and other things anyway.

I prefer other stocks a bit more at the current moment like Google Amazon Microsoft who are cheaper buys with more interesting Diversified businesses in my opinion. for example you look at Google right they actually have more smartphone operating system market share with Android than than Apple and yet Android isn't even the first thing you think about when you look at Google's business because they're so well Diversified into so many other things that they do that are also even more profitable for them and yet their market cap is like two trillion billion dollars less than Apple on top of that Apple stock trades over 80% more expensive than the sector on Peg which is fine when you're you know that damn profitable but it's also the second highest on today's list with broadcom being the cheapest and I just feel that as a more long-term growth oriented investor I'm not as attracted to their almost flat performance on the top and bottom line really these past two years that we've seen but sometimes there even be negative growth because of the cyclicality of smartphone sales and how much they rely on that.
